properties.description: Indigenous River tribes (such as the Tunxis, Poquonock, and Podunk) lived on the land that European settlers later converted into today's Hartford County (overlaid in blue). This map of the 1620s, created by Hayden Griswold in 1930, imagined well-defined borders among native people, similar to today's town boundaries.

The first three English settlements on the Connecticut River-- Windsor (red), Hartford (blue) and Wethersfield (green) -- later became known as the Constitution Towns, for adopting principles of self-governance in the Fundamental Orders of 1639.
Farmington incorporated as a town in 1645, after English farmers moved to the west of the three original settlements.
Hartford County was established as one of Connecticut's four original counties in 1666, and stretched southward to include territory not inside the county today, such as Middletown.
Simsbury officially became a town in 1670, by a petition of English settlers to the colonial government.
Glastonbury incorporated as a town in 1693, when residents on the eastern bank of the Connecticut River received permission to split off from Wethersfield.

Hartford County expanded many times to its largest extent in 1722 (shown in red), stretching to Waterbury in the west and Windham in the east. Later, these borders retracted due to the creation of three new counties: Litchfield (1751), Tolland, and Middlesex (both in 1785).
Suffield (red) and Enfield (blue) became towns in Hartford County when annexed from Massachusetts in 1749. Somers also joined Connecticut, but later became part of Tolland County.
Towns in the Hartford area (overlaid in blue) on a 1766 map of the Connecticut colony by Moses Park. Borders may not match precisely due to the original map and georectification process.

East Windsor incorporated in 1768, when residents on the eastern bank of the Connecticut River received permission to separate from Windsor. Also, Simsbury and Suffield expanded northward when Connecticut unilaterally extended its border into Massachusetts in 1774.
Southington was formally established as a town in 1779, when residents of "South Farmington" separated from Farmington and shortened their community name.
Towns in the Hartford area (overlaid in blue) on a 1780 Connecticut map, by Covens and Mortier in Amsterdam. Borders may not match precisely due to the original map and georectification process.
East Hartford officially became a town in 1783, when residents on the east bank of the Connecticut River separated from Hartford.
Bristol (red) and Berlin (blue) incorporated as towns when they separated from Farmington in 1785.
Granby incorporated in 1786, when residents on the north side of Simsbury separated to form their own town. Also, East Windsor had a small change in its border with Tolland County in 1789.
Towns in the Hartford area (overlaid in blue) on a 1795 map of Connecticut by Amos Doolittle. Borders may not match precisely due to the original map and georectification process.
Although Hartland incorporated in 1761, the town did not become part of Hartford County until it was transferred from Litchfield County in 1796.

Marlborough became a town in 1803, created from Glastonbury, Hebron (Tolland County), and Colchester (New London County). Also, Glastonbury, Berlin, and Southington had minor border changes from 1796-98.
In an 1804 border compromise, Granby (red) lost land to neighboring Southwick, Massachusetts, but Suffield (blue) retained its territory.

Canton (red) separated from Simsbury, and Burlington (blue) split away from Farmington, in 1806. Although the outline of Hartford County has remained relatively stable from this point onward, interior borders continued to change.
Hartford County towns (overlaid in blue) on an 1811 Connecticut map by Warren Moses and George Gillet.
Manchester incorporated as its own town when it broke away from East Hartford in 1823.
Avon officially became a town when it divided from the north side of Farmington in 1830.

Bloomfield incorporated as a town in 1835, and its borders expanded in the early 1840s. The area was originally named Wintonbury because its land came from three neighboring towns: Windsor, Farmington, and Simsbury.
Rocky Hill incorporated as a town in 1843, when it separated from Wethersfield.
South Windsor officially became a town in 1845, when it divided from East Windsor.
New Britain officially became a town when it split from Berlin in 1850, and later incorporated as a city in 1871.
The "West Division" broke away from Hartford to establish the town of West Hartford (red) in 1854. That same year, Windsor Locks (blue) incorporated as a separate town from Windsor.
Hartford County towns (overlaid in blue) on E.M. Woodford's 1855 map.
East Granby incorporated in 1858, on land drawn from Granby and Windsor Locks.
Plainville formally became its own town when it split from Farmington in 1869. Since its founding in 1640, Farmington subdivided into nine separate towns.
Newington, the most recent town in Hartford County, was created when it separated from Wethersfield in 1871.
Hartford County towns (overlaid in blue) on an 1893 Connecticut atlas by E.M. Hurd.
The Hartford town line extended north when Windsor ceded land for Keney Park in 1897.
The towns of Hartford County as their boundaries have remained from 1897 to the present.
